title: Installation issue: flux-core: Concretization error due to libxml2 variant

labels.name: triage
labels.description: The issue needs to be prioritized

body:
### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ spack install flux-core@master
==> Error: An unsatisfiable variant constraint has been detected for spec:

    gettext@0.20.1%gcc@7.4.0+bzip2+curses+git~libunistring+libxml2+tar+xz arch=linux-ubuntu18.04-broadwell


while trying to concretize the partial spec:

    python@3.7.6%gcc@7.4.0+bz2+ctypes+dbm~debug~libxml2+lzma~nis~optimizations+pic+pyexpat+pythoncmd+readline+shared+sqlite3+ssl~tix~tkinter~ucs4~uuid+zlib arch=linux-ubuntu18.04-broadwell
        ^pkgconf@1.6.3%gcc@7.4.0 arch=linux-ubuntu18.04-broadwell


python requires gettext variant ~libxml2, but spec asked for +libxml2
```

### Platform and user environment

I am using Github Actions with `ubuntu-latest` as the OS (ubuntu 18.04)
```commandline
$ spack get compilers
compilers:
- compiler:
    spec: clang@6.0.1
    paths:
      cc: /usr/bin/clang-6.0
      cxx: /usr/bin/clang++-6.0
      f77:
      fc:
    flags: {}
    operating_system: ubuntu18.04
    target: x86_64
    modules: []
    environment:
      unset: []
    extra_rpaths: []
- compiler:
    spec: gcc@7.4.0
    paths:
      cc: /usr/bin/gcc-7
      cxx: /usr/bin/g++-7
      f77:
      fc:
    flags: {}
    operating_system: ubuntu18.04
    target: x86_64
    modules: []
    environment: {}
    extra_rpaths: []
``` 

You can view the full workflow log from the github action here: https://github.com/flux-framework/flux-spack/runs/431181960?check_suite_focus=true

### Additional information

This doesn't seem to be an issue on my mac, so I wonder if it is somehow related to the OS or the architecture (broadwell).

Also worth noting that `spack install flux-core@master ^gettext~libxml2` works just fine.  If necessary, I am happy to add a hint/conflict in the `flux-core` package to make this work.  But that seems a bit heavy handed.
